ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: At least two conduct disorder criteria are rated threshold
Conduct Disorder Dx (3+ symptoms at threshold)
Antisocial Personality Disorder Diagnosis (3 threshold symptoms plus conduct disorder)

Verbal aggression (e.g., temper tantrums, tirades, verbal arguments or fights) or physical aggression toward property, animals, or other individuals, occurring twice weekly, on average, for a period of 3 months. The physical aggression does not result in damage or destruction of property and does not result in physical injury to animals or other individuals.
Notes: 0= Not Assessed; 1= Absent or false; 2= Subthreshold; 3= Threshold

ElementDescription: Recurrent behavioral outbursts representing a failure to control aggressive impulses as manifested by either of the following
Notes: 0= Not Assessed; 1= Absent or false; 2= Subthreshold; 3= Threshold

ElementDescription: The magnitude of aggressiveness expressed during the recurrent outbursts is grossly out of proportion to the provocation or to any precipitating psychosocial stressors.
Notes: 0= Not Assessed; 1= Absent or false; 2= Subthreshold; 3= Threshold

ElementDescription: The recurrent aggressive outbursts are not premeditated (i.e., they are impulsive and/or anger-based) and are not committed to achieve some tangible objective (e.g., money, power, intimidation).
Notes: 0= Not Assessed; 1= Absent or false; 2= Subthreshold; 3= Threshold

7. Has recurrent suspicions, without justification, regarding fidelity of spouse or sexual partner. A. Have you sometimes suspected that your spouse or partner has been unfaithful? Tell me about that. (What clues did you have? What did you do about it? Were you right?) 2=examples of unjustified suspicions with several partners or on several occasions with the same partner OR acknowledges trait
Notes: 0 = Absent; 1 = Subthreshold; 2 = Threshold; 3 = Inadequate information; -900 = Missing; -300 = N/A Section Header: Paranoid PD Criterion A. A pervasive distrust and suspiciousness of others such that their motives are interpreted as malevolant, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts as indicated by four (or more) of the following:

ElementDescription: 1. Ideas of Reference (excluding delusions of reference) A. When you are out in public and see people talking, do you often feel that they are talking about you? Tell me more about this. B. When you are around people, do you often get the feeling that you are being watched or stared at? Tell me more about this. C. Do you often get the feeling that the words to a song or something in a movie or on TV has a special meaning for you in particular? Tell me more about this.   2 = several examples
Notes: 0 = Absent; 1 = Subthreshold; 2 = Threshold; 3 = Inadequate information; -900 = Missing; -300 = N/A Section Header: Schizotypal PD Criterion A. Pervasive patterns of social and interpersonal deficits marked by acute discomfort with, and reduced capacity for, close relationships as well as by cognitive or perceptual distortions and eccentricities of behavior, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by five (or more) of the following Please note: Timeframe for these ratings is lifetime

ElementDescription: 2. Odd beliefs or magical thinking that influences behavior and is inconsistent with sub-cultural norms (e.g., superstitiousness, belief in clairvoyance, telepathy, or 'sixth sense'; in children and adolescents, bizarre fantasies or preoccupations).  A. Are you a superstitious person? If yes, what are some of your superstitions? How have they affected what you say or do? Do you know other people who fo these things?  B. Have you ever felt that you could make things happen just by making a wish or thinking about them? Tell me about that. (How did it affect you?) C. Have you had personal experiences with the supernatural? Tell me about that. (How did it affect you?) D. Do you believe that you have a 'sixth' sense' that allows you to know and predict things? Tell me about that. (How does it affect you?)   2= several examples of such phenomena that influenced behavior and are consistent with sub-cultural norms
Notes: 0 = Absent; 1 = Subthreshold; 2 = Threshold; 3 = Inadequate information; -900 = Missing; -300 = N/A Section Header: Schizotypal PD Criterion A. Pervasive patterns of social and interpersonal deficits marked by acute discomfort with, and reduced capacity for, close relationships as well as by cognitive or perceptual distortions and eccentricities of behavior, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by five (or more) of the following Please note: Timeframe for these ratings is lifetime

ElementDescription: 3. Unusual perceptional experiences, including bodily illusions.  A. Do you often have the feeling that everything is unreal, that you are detached from your body or mind, or that you are an outside observer of your own thoughts or movements? Give me some examples. (Were you drinking or taking drugs at the time?) B. Do you often see things that other people don't see? Give me some examples. (Were you drinking or taking drugs at the time?) C. Do you often hear a voice softly speaking your name? Tell me more about that. (Were you drinking or taking drugs at the time?) D. Have you had the sense that some person or force is around you, even though you cannot see anyone? Tell me more about that. (Were you drinking or taking drugs at the time?)   2= several examples of unusual perceptual experiences not due to substance use
Notes: 0 = Absent; 1 = Subthreshold; 2 = Threshold; 3 = Inadequate information; -900 = Missing; -300 = N/A Section Header: Schizotypal PD Criterion A. Pervasive patterns of social and interpersonal deficits marked by acute discomfort with, and reduced capacity for, close relationships as well as by cognitive or perceptual distortions and eccentricities of behavior, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by five (or more) of the following Please note: Timeframe for these ratings is lifetime

ElementDescription: 4. Odd thinking and speech (e.g., vague, circumstantial, metaphorical, over-elaborate, or stereotyped). Observed during interview.
Notes: 0 = Absent; 1 = Subthreshold; 2 = Threshold; 3 = Inadequate information; -900 = Missing; -300 = N/A Section Header: Schizotypal PD Criterion A. Pervasive patterns of social and interpersonal deficits marked by acute discomfort with, and reduced capacity for, close relationships as well as by cognitive or perceptual distortions and eccentricities of behavior, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by five (or more) of the following Please note: Timeframe for these ratings is lifetime

ElementDescription: 8. Lack of close friends or confidants other than first-degree relatives. A. Are there very few people who you're really close to outside of your immediate family? How many close friends do you have? 2 = no close friends other than first-degree relatives.

ElementDescription: 9. Excessive social anxiety that does not diminish with familiarity and tends to be associated with paranoid fears rather than negative judgements about self.  A. Do you often feel nervous when you are with other people you don't know very well? What are you nervous about? Is it because you are worried about being taken advantage of or hurt in some way rather than being rejected or criticized? (Are you still anxious even after you've known them for a while?) 2 = acknowledges excessive anxiety that does not diminish with familiarity related to suspiciousness about other people's motives.

ElementDescription: (If [chrschizotypal_threshold_2]>4) If there is evidence of a psychotic disorder:  Does this happen only when you are having (symptoms of psychotic disorder)? If there is evidence of prolonged excessive alcohol or drug use that results in symptoms that resemble schizotypal PD: Does this happen only when you are drunk or high or withdrawing from alcohol or drugs? If there is evidence of a General Medical Condition (GMC) that causes symptoms that resemble schizotypal PD: Were you like that before (onset of GMC)? B. Does not occur exclusively during the course of Schizophrenia, a Bipolar Disorder or Depressive Disorder With Psychotic Features, another Psychotic Disorder, or Autism Spectrum Disorder.
Notes: 0 = None of these conditions account for 5 or more SPD-like symptoms; 1 = One or more of these conditions account for all but 4 or fewer SPD-like symptoms; 3 = Inadequate information; -900 = Missing; -300 = N/A Section Header: Schizotypal PD Criterion B. Does not occur exclusively during the course of Schizophrenia, a Bipolar Disorder or Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features, another Psychotic Disorder, or Autism Spectrum Disorder. This criterion should be rated 'NO' if there is a preexisting diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder.
